explanation: The MISRA requirement concerns well-formed for loops and explicitly includes the behaviour of any functions called within a for-statement body. Although lfs_file_sync itself has no for loop, it calls lfs_file_sync_ and lfs_mlist_isopen; any for-loops (or macros that expand to for-loops) in those functions would affect compliance. Therefore you must inspect the implementation of lfs_file_sync_ and every function it calls (lfs_file_flush, lfs_pair_isnull, lfs_bd_sync, lfs_ctz_tole32, lfs_dir_commit) to ensure their for-loops (and any loop counters/side-effects) obey the rule. Additionally, the target uses several macros (LFS_LOCK, LFS_UNLOCK, LFS_ASSERT, LFS_TRACE) that may expand to code containing for-loops or side-effecting expressions; their expansions must be checked as they are part of the target function's observable behaviour. Inspecting these symbols will allow determination whether any for-loop in the call chain violates the stated MISRA rule.
